bullets.text: U.S. CPI rose 0.2% in January; shelter costs remained a key driver, signaling sticky housing inflation despite broader easing.
Real average hourly earnings rose 0.3% in January, improving purchasing power and supporting consumer demand.
Early IRS data show average tax refunds up about 11%, potentially boosting near-term household cash flow and retail spending.
Markets appear resilient to overlapping geopolitical and political crises, suggesting risk appetite remains strong or investors expect limited economic spillover.
AI-driven volatility is spreading beyond tech; analysts warn AI disruption could trigger credit-market stress and pressure cyclicals like trucking and real estate.
Trump-era tariffs are creating a record $3.5B U.S. Customs bond funding shortfall, raising importer liquidity and compliance risks.
Venezuela oil sales topped $1B; proceeds will no longer be routed to a Qatar account, signaling a shift in sanctions-related payment arrangements.
Munich Security Conference: European leaders increasingly accept a post–"old order" security landscape, implying higher European defense burdens and less U.S.-centric NATO assumptions.
U.S. DHS sought identities behind anti-ICE posts and faced scrutiny over alleged intimidation, intensifying civil-liberties and rule-of-law tensions amid looming shutdown risks.
China’s "Lunar New Year AI war": major platforms use giveaways and subsidies to capture users, highlighting intense competition and potentially margin-damaging AI customer acquisition.
OpenAI removed access to a "sycophancy-prone" GPT-4o variant, underscoring the operational and reputational costs of alignment failures in widely deployed AI systems.
Asteroid Bennu samples suggest new pathways for prebiotic chemistry, strengthening evidence that asteroids can deliver or synthesize life-relevant organics.
Researchers made microplastics glow to track their behavior inside the body, enabling clearer exposure and toxicity studies with potential public-health implications.
